sn4.13:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati maddakucchismiṃ migadāye.
sn4.13:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Maddakucchi deer park.

sn4.13:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavato pādo sakalikāya khato hoti,
sn4.13:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha’s foot had been cut by a wooden splinter.

sn4.13:1.4.pli: bhusā sudaṃ bhagavato vedanā vattanti sārīrikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā asātā amanāpā.
sn4.13:1.4.eng: The Buddha was stricken by harrowing pains; physical feelings that were painful, sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, and disagreeable.

sn4.13:1.5.pli: Tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāseti avihaññamāno.
sn4.13:1.5.eng: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.

sn4.13:1.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
sn4.13:1.6.eng: And then he spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.

sn4.13:1.7.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.13:1.7.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.13:2.1.eng: “Are you feeble that you lie down? <j>Or are you drunk on poetry?
sn4.13:2.1.comm: Māra thinks that “drunk on poetry” (kāveyyamatta, see SN 8.12:2.1) means literally drunk. In Rig Veda 10.131.4, Indra, drunk on an excess of soma, needs the illicit beer of Namuci (= Māra) to revive him. Perhaps we see in this phrase an echo of the Vedic tradition of taking intoxicants so that the god speaks through you in inspired verse.

sn4.13:2.2.pli: Atthā nu te sampacurā na santi;
sn4.13:2.2.eng: Are your goals not amply satisfied?

sn4.13:3.1.eng: “I’m not feeble that I lie down, <j>nor am I drunk on poetry.

sn4.13:3.2.eng: Having reached the goal, I’m rid of sorrow.

sn4.13:3.4.eng: I lie down full of sympathy for all living creatures.

sn4.13:4.1.eng: Even those with a dart stuck in the breast,

sn4.13:4.2.eng: piercing the heart moment by moment,

sn4.13:4.3.eng: are able to get some sleep.

sn4.13:4.4.eng: So why not I, whose dart is drawn out?

sn4.13:5.1.pli: Jaggaṃ na saṅke napi bhemi sottuṃ,
sn4.13:5.1.eng: I don’t lie awake tense, nor do I fear to sleep.

sn4.13:5.2.eng: The days and nights don’t disturb me,

sn4.13:5.3.eng: as I see no decline for myself in the world.

sn4.13:5.4.eng: That’s why I lie down full of sympathy for all living creatures.”

sn4.13:6.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.13:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.14:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati ekasālāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
sn4.14:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans near the brahmin village of Ekasālā.
sn4.14:1.1.comm: Ekasālā (“One Hall”) is mentioned only here in Pali, although a village of the same name is occasionally mention in Sanskrit and epigraphical sources. Compare the similarly-named villages of Sālā (MN 41:1.2, etc.) and Pañcasālā (SN 4.18:1.1).

sn4.14:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā gihiparisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn4.14:1.2.eng: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.

sn4.14:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo mahatiyā gihiparisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn4.14:2.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly of laypeople.

sn4.14:2.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
sn4.14:2.3.eng: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

sn4.14:2.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.14:2.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.14:3.1.comm: The challenge and response are similar to SN 10.2.

sn4.14:3.4.eng: don’t get caught up in favoring and opposing.”
sn4.14:3.4.comm: Māra is projecting. Since he only uses words to manipulate people and get what he wants, he assumes that others do the same.

sn4.14:4.2.eng: out of compassion for their welfare.

sn4.14:5.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.14:5.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.15:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn4.15:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn4.15:1.3.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.15:1.3.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.15:2.2.comm: Elsewhere there are mind-made deities who are said to “wander in midair” (antalikkhacara, DN 1:2.2.3). The idea goes back to the Vedas (eg. Rig Veda 6.58.3, antarikṣe caranti).

sn4.15:3.3.eng: desire for these is gone from me.

sn4.15:4.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.15:4.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.16:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn4.16:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the five grasping aggregates.

sn4.16:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn4.16:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn4.16:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn4.16:2.2.eng: “This ascetic Gotama is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the five grasping aggregates.

sn4.16:2.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn4.16:2.3.eng: And the mendicants are paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn4.16:2.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
sn4.16:2.4.eng: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

sn4.16:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā pattā abbhokāse nikkhittā honti.
sn4.16:3.1.eng: At that time several alms bowls were placed in the open air.

sn4.16:3.2.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā balībaddavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena te pattā tenupasaṅkami.
sn4.16:3.2.eng: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of an ox and approached those bowls.
sn4.16:3.2.comm: The ox was a metaphor for the senses, which are “yoked” like an ox by desire (SN 35.232:4.1). The relation between Māra, sense control, and oxen is emphasized in SN 4.19.

sn4.16:3.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn4.16:3.3.eng: One of the mendicants said to another,

sn4.16:3.4.eng: “Mendicant, mendicant, that ox will break the bowls.”
sn4.16:3.4.comm: The bowl is a symbol of mendicant life. Within it is the food that sustains life, but which also tempts desire. The rampant ox is unrestrained desire, which threatens to crack open the bounds of monastic life.

sn4.16:3.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn4.16:3.5.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to that mendicant,

sn4.16:3.7.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tumhākaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato”ti.
sn4.16:3.7.eng: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!”

sn4.16:3.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.16:3.8.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:

sn4.16:4.2.comm: These are the five aggregates. To fit the metre, vedayitaṁ (“the felt”) is used for vedanā (“feeling”), and saṅkhataṁ “the chosen”) is used for saṅkhārā (“choices”).

sn4.16:4.3.eng: ‘I am not this’ and ‘this is not mine’;

sn4.16:4.4.eng: that’s how to be free of desire for them.

sn4.16:5.3.eng: though Māra and his army chase everywhere

sn4.17:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn4.17:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn4.17:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn4.17:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the six fields of contact.
sn4.17:1.2.comm: Continuing the theme of Māra and the senses.

sn4.17:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn4.17:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn4.17:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ upādāya bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sappahaṃseti.
sn4.17:2.2.eng: “This ascetic Gotama is educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk on the topic of the six fields of contact.

sn4.17:2.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn4.17:2.3.eng: And those mendicants are paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn4.17:2.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
sn4.17:2.4.eng: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

sn4.17:2.5.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato avidūre mahantaṃ bhayabheravaṃ saddamakāsi, apissudaṃ pathavī maññe undrīyati. Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn4.17:2.5.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and made a terrifyingly loud noise close by him. It seemed as if the earth were shattering, so that one of the mendicants said to another,

sn4.17:2.6.eng: “Mendicant, mendicant, it seems like the earth is shattering!”

sn4.17:2.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn4.17:2.7.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to that mendicant,

sn4.17:2.9.pli: Māro eso pāpimā tumhākaṃ vicakkhukammāya āgato”ti.
sn4.17:2.9.eng: That’s Māra the Wicked come to pull the wool over your eyes!”

sn4.17:2.10.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.17:2.10.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:

sn4.17:3.2.eng: touches, and ideas, the lot of them—

sn4.17:4.1.eng: But a mindful disciple of the Buddha

sn4.17:4.3.eng: Having slipped free of Māra’s dominion,

sn4.18:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati pañcasālāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
sn4.18:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans near the brahmin village of Pañcasālā.

sn4.18:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcasālāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme kumārikānaṃ pāhunakāni bhavanti.
sn4.18:1.2.eng: Now at that time in Pañcasālā the young maidens were occupied with guests.
sn4.18:1.2.comm: Pāhunaka means “(honored) guest”. When such arrived they were to be looked after (Mil 5.1.2:11.2). It seems that there was an influx of travelers who were being attended by the youngsters. Māra took advantage of the situation to possess the adults, the implication being that they were already stretched thin. The commentary, alternatively, offers a story of a gift festival. | The youngsters’ gender varies in manuscripts, sometimes feminine, sometimes masculine (i.e. universal). But the commentary favors the feminine.

sn4.18:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya pañcasālaṃ brāhmaṇagāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn4.18:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Pañcasālā for alms.

sn4.18:1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcasāleyyakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā mārena pāpimatā anvāviṭṭhā bhavanti:
sn4.18:1.4.eng: Now at that time Māra had possessed the brahmins and householders of Pañcasālā, so that they thought,

sn4.18:1.5.eng: “Don’t let the ascetic Gotama get any alms!”

sn4.18:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yathādhotena pattena pañcasālaṃ brāhmaṇagāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi tathādhotena pattena paṭikkami.
sn4.18:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha left the village with his bowl as clean-washed as it was when he entered for alms.

sn4.18:2.2.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn4.18:2.2.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and said to him,

sn4.18:2.3.eng: “Well, ascetic, did you get any alms?”

sn4.18:2.4.pli: “Tathā nu tvaṃ, pāpima, akāsi yathāhaṃ piṇḍaṃ na labheyyan”ti.
sn4.18:2.4.eng: “Wicked One, did you make sure I didn’t get any alms?”

sn4.18:2.5.pli: “Tena hi, bhante, bhagavā dutiyampi pañcasālaṃ brāhmaṇagāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisatu.
sn4.18:2.5.eng: “Well then, sir, let the Buddha enter Pañcasālā a second time for alms.

sn4.18:2.6.pli: Tathāhaṃ karissāmi yathā bhagavā piṇḍaṃ lacchatī”ti.
sn4.18:2.6.eng: I’ll make sure you get alms.”

sn4.18:3.3.eng: Wicked One, do you imagine that

sn4.18:4.1.eng: Let us live so very happily,

sn4.18:4.4.eng: like the gods of streaming radiance.”

sn4.18:5.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.18:5.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.19:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
sn4.19:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk about extinguishment.

sn4.19:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn4.19:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn4.19:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo bhikkhūnaṃ nibbānapaṭisaṃyuttāya dhammiyā kathāya …pe…
sn4.19:2.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is giving a Dhamma talk about extinguishment … and the mendicants are listening well.

sn4.19:2.3.pli: yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
sn4.19:2.3.eng: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

sn4.19:2.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā kassakavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā mahantaṃ naṅgalaṃ khandhe karitvā dīghapācanayaṭṭhiṃ gahetvā haṭahaṭakeso sāṇasāṭinivattho kaddamamakkhitehi pādehi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn4.19:2.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked manifested in the form of a farmer carrying a large plough on his shoulder. He held a long goad, his hair was messy, he was clad in sunn hemp, and his feet were muddy. He went up to the Buddha and said to him,

sn4.19:2.5.eng: “So, ascetic, did you happen to see any oxen?”

sn4.19:2.6.eng: “But what have you to do with oxen, Wicked One?”
sn4.19:2.6.comm: Good question! As we have seen in SN 4.16, the senses are yoked by desire like an ox (SN 35.232:4.1).

sn4.19:2.7.pli: “Mameva, samaṇa, cakkhu, mama rūpā, mama cakkhusamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.
sn4.19:2.7.eng: “Mine alone, ascetic, is the eye, mine are sights, mine is the field of eye contact consciousness.
sn4.19:2.7.comm: “Field of eye contact consciousness” (cakkhusamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṁ) sounds like a Buddhist psychological term, and the commentary explains it in line with much later Abhidhamma. But it is not standard. More likely Māra is simply using an odd term because he is a fake.

sn4.19:2.8.eng: Where can you escape me, ascetic?

sn4.19:2.13.pli: mameva, samaṇa, mano, mama dhammā, mama manosamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.
sn4.19:2.13.eng: mind, mine are ideas, mine is the field of mind contact consciousness.

sn4.19:2.14.eng: Where can you escape me, ascetic?”

sn4.19:3.1.pli: “Taveva, pāpima, cakkhu, tava rūpā, tava cakkhusamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.
sn4.19:3.1.eng: “Yours alone, Wicked One, is the eye, yours are sights, yours is the field of eye contact consciousness.

sn4.19:3.2.pli: Yattha ca kho, pāpima, natthi cakkhu, natthi rūpā, natthi cakkhusamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ, agati tava tattha, pāpima.
sn4.19:3.2.eng: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye contact consciousness—you have no place there, Wicked One!

sn4.19:3.3.pli: Taveva, pāpima, sotaṃ, tava saddā, tava sotasamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.

sn4.19:3.4.pli: Yattha ca kho, pāpima, natthi sotaṃ, natthi saddā, natthi sotasamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ, agati tava tattha, pāpima.

sn4.19:3.5.pli: Taveva, pāpima, ghānaṃ, tava gandhā, tava ghānasamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.

sn4.19:3.6.pli: Yattha ca kho, pāpima, natthi ghānaṃ, natthi gandhā, natthi ghānasamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ, agati tava tattha, pāpima.

sn4.19:3.7.pli: Taveva, pāpima, jivhā, tava rasā, tava jivhāsamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ …pe…

sn4.19:3.8.pli: taveva, pāpima, kāyo, tava phoṭṭhabbā, tava kāyasamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ …pe…

sn4.19:3.9.pli: taveva, pāpima, mano, tava dhammā, tava manosamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ.
sn4.19:3.9.eng: mind, yours are ideas, yours is the field of mind contact consciousness.

sn4.19:3.10.pli: Yattha ca kho, pāpima, natthi mano, natthi dhammā, natthi manosamphassaviññāṇāyatanaṃ, agati tava tattha, pāpimā”ti.
sn4.19:3.10.eng: Where there is no mind, no ideas, no mind contact consciousness—you have no place there, Wicked One!”

sn4.19:5.1.eng: “The things they speak of aren’t mine;

sn4.19:5.2.eng: I’m not someone who speaks like that.

sn4.19:5.4.eng: you won’t even see the path I take.”

sn4.2:0.3.eng: In the Form of an Elephant King

sn4.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn4.2:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn4.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn4.2:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.
sn4.2:1.3.comm: At SN 41.4:3.3 such a rain is regarded as pleasantly cooling.

sn4.2:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo mahantaṃ hatthirājavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
sn4.2:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, manifested in the form of a huge elephant king and approached him.

sn4.2:1.5.eng: Its head was like a huge block of soapstone.

sn4.2:1.7.eng: Its tusks were like pure silver.

sn4.2:1.9.eng: Its trunk was like a long plough pole.

sn4.2:1.11.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.2:1.11.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:

sn4.2:2.2.eng: you’ve made forms beautiful and ugly.

sn4.2:3.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.2:3.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.20:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati himavantapadese araññakuṭikāyaṃ.
sn4.20:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans, in a wilderness hut on the slopes of the Himalayas.

sn4.20:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn4.20:1.2.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn4.20:1.3.pli: “sakkā nu kho rajjaṃ kāretuṃ ahanaṃ aghātayaṃ ajinaṃ ajāpayaṃ asocaṃ asocāpayaṃ dhammenā”ti?
sn4.20:1.3.eng: “I wonder if it’s possible to rule legitimately, without killing or having someone kill for you; without conquering or having someone conquer for you; without sorrowing or causing sorrow?”
sn4.20:1.3.comm: Legend has it that the Buddha’s destiny was either to be Awakened or become a Wheel Turning Monarch. If he took the second path, he would indeed have ruled without violence (MN 91:5.8). Here the Buddha wonders whether this is really possible.

sn4.20:2.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn4.20:2.1.eng: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing the Buddha’s train of thought, went up to him and said,

sn4.20:2.2.pli: “kāretu, bhante, bhagavā rajjaṃ, kāretu, sugato, rajjaṃ ahanaṃ aghātayaṃ ajinaṃ ajāpayaṃ asocaṃ asocāpayaṃ dhammenā”ti.
sn4.20:2.2.eng: “Rule, Blessed One! Rule, Holy One! Rule legitimately, without killing or having someone kill for you; without conquering or having someone conquer for you; without sorrowing or causing sorrow!”
sn4.20:2.2.comm: Māra knows that even the most righteous ruler is afflicted with compromises and remains within his realm.

sn4.20:2.3.pli: “Kiṃ pana me tvaṃ, pāpima, passasi yaṃ maṃ tvaṃ evaṃ vadesi:
sn4.20:2.3.eng: “But what do you see, Wicked One, that you say this to me?”

sn4.20:2.4.pli: ‘kāretu, bhante, bhagavā rajjaṃ, kāretu sugato, rajjaṃ ahanaṃ aghātayaṃ ajinaṃ ajāpayaṃ asocaṃ asocāpayaṃ dhammenā’”ti?

sn4.20:2.5.pli: “Bhagavatā kho, bhante, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
sn4.20:2.5.eng: “The Blessed One, sir, has developed and cultivated the four bases for psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them.

sn4.20:2.6.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno ca, bhante, bhagavā himavantaṃ pabbatarājaṃ suvaṇṇaṃ tveva adhimucceyya suvaṇṇañca panassā”ti.
sn4.20:2.6.eng: If he wished, the Blessed One need only determine that the Himalaya, king of mountains, was gold, and it would turn into gold.”

sn4.20:3.2.eng: entirely of native gold, and double it—

sn4.20:3.3.eng: it’s still not enough for one!

sn4.20:3.4.eng: Knowing this, live a moral life.

sn4.20:4.1.eng: When a personage has seen where suffering comes from

sn4.20:4.2.eng: how could they incline towards sensual pleasures?

sn4.20:4.3.eng: Realizing that attachment is a chain in the world,

sn4.20:4.4.eng: a personage would train to remove it.”

sn4.20:5.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.20:5.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
